GeneDef.label: vacuum impervious
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene have hardier circulatory and respiratory systems, reducing the rate at which hypoxia builds up in the vacuum of space.

GeneDef.label: cryostasis
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene do not suffer fatal hypothermia. Instead, their bodies gradually slow down and enter a dormant state when exposed to extreme cold, and they can awaken safely once warmed.

GeneDef.label: mild oxygen sensitivity
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene are slightly averse to oxygen-rich environments. In breathable atmosphere, they experience minor respiratory and neurological strain, accompanied by a subtle discomfort with each breath.

GeneDef.label: intense oxygen sensitivity
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene suffer severe discomfort and reduced bodily function in oxygenated environments. Exposure to breathable air causes pain, weakness, and labored breathing, making planetary survival difficult.

GeneDef.label: extreme oxygen sensitivity
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene cannot survive in oxygen-rich environments. Exposure to breathable atmospheres causes rapid lung failure and eventual death. Only the vacuum of space or low-oxygen gravship environments can sustain them.

GeneDef.label: vacuum efficiency
GeneDef.description: Carriers of this gene thrive in space. Their bodies are highly adapted to zero-atmosphere conditions, allowing for faster and more efficient work outside planetary environments. However, they function poorly on terrestrial surfaces.
